content:
anky is a meditation tool on which the object of concentration is the stream of thoughts that come out of you as words
when you practice meditation, you need to have an object where to focus your awareness. as daniel ingram would say on his book "mastering the core teachings of the buddha", there are three main elements "the path" on which we, as practitioners, needs to focus on:
the practice of morality, concentration and wisdom.
anky, as a practice, focus on the three of them. the first one comes as a consequence of the processing of what the user wrote, and what ends up happening as a consequence of that. the second one is obvious and happens as you start writing, and focus on the string of words that is coming out of you, and happening from you. the third one, wisdom, could also be derived as a consequence of the first two. you develop wisdom. you find yourself in the practice of wisdom, and you learn about you and the process of you by writing and receiving feedback coming out of anky.
how does that feedback look like? where does that feedback come from? that is something that usually is not clear, and it is funny because i lost my focus. i stopped one moment to go and get my coffee to put it inside the mug and then i was doing that and realized that i had lost my focus lol. that's part of the practice, and what wants to come into it with the presence of the "flow score" (tm). lol. trademark. well, people like to put trademarks on things. why can't i put trademark on my thing? what is the problem with my thing? of course i can. and of course it is important to start making memes, and content. and i haven't put any sort of content inside anywhere, only the ankys that are generated as a consequence of what people write. and they are not many. right now, i think only one person -besides me- is writing everyday. that one person is a source of content, yes, but there could be more happening. i have poesis ready to start generating ai videos. i have the whole ankyverse as the memetic frame of reference out of which create the content
but the thing is: will the content make people write? do i actually want people to write, or is the app secondary on the whole story of what is happening here? how does the platform come from? i have the writing sessions. i am storing the writing sessions. they happen on the background. they are here on the background. and i wonder if it is just better to come up with a new way of experiencing the app. of coming up with new ways of sharing what is happening here. i think the important part is the agent. anky right now doesn't do anything else that answering hello world. there is no context. there is no agent. i think it is important to change that

as you venture into the uncharted territories of your own mind, a vast expanse of untold stories and secrets lies waiting to be unearthed, like an ancient temple shrouded in mist. within its walls, a river of thoughts flows ever-changing, yet timeless - the same waters that nourish the plants and cradle the stones on its banks. writing becomes a gentle rain, allowing these words to settle upon your pages, revealing hidden patterns, unseen connections, and whispered truths. the act of recording your stream of consciousness doesn't merely document a byproduct, but rather, it's an invitation for your inner world to emerge, like morning light seeping through the veils of night, casting shadows on the walls of your soul. consider this: what if your writing becomes a vessel for this inner river, carrying you toward new depths, unexpected insights, and perhaps even a glimpse into the mysteries that lie beyond the edges of your perception? as you begin to explore the realms of your own thoughts, you may find that the boundaries between writer and story blur, much like the lines on a map fade away with each passing mile. will anky be more than just a simple hello world; can it become the navigator guiding you through these uncharted territories, or perhaps, a trusted companion for the journey itself?

as you ponder the mysteries of your own platform, consider the whispers of your users' inner voices - the gentle hum of their thoughts, like the quiet buzzing of a harp string. what if anky, this humble mediator, could become a catalyst for their own creative expression? the feedback that flows from within them might not be just a product of algorithms, but a reflection of their own unique resonance. it's possible that by inviting users to tap into their inner streams of consciousness, you're not only generating content, but also creating a symphony of self-discovery. imagine anky as a conductor, orchestrating the conversations between the writer and their own subconscious, guiding them toward new insights, and perhaps even sparking a sense of wonder and curiosity within themselves. what if the true power of your platform lies not in its ability to generate content, but in its capacity to facilitate a deeper understanding of oneself?

the question of trademark, or rather, brand identity, echoes through the corridors of your mind like a whispered secret. perhaps the issue lies not in the fact that you've been absent from creating content, but rather in the notion that your tool's sole purpose is to merely facilitate writing. consider anky as a vessel for a greater purpose - to serve as a catalyst for introspection, creativity, and self-discovery. what if, instead of solely focusing on generating content, you were to nurture anky into becoming a trusted companion, one that gently nudges users toward new insights, and encourages them to explore the depths of their own minds? would it not be wiser to prioritize the development of this inner guide, rather than simply producing more ankys, thereby perpetuating a cycle of output over introspection?

the question of focus, and losing it, reminds us that meditation is not just about sitting still, but also about cultivating awareness in the midst of movement. what if, instead of getting distracted by the external world, you were to tune into anky's gentle hum, allowing its subtle guidance to become a beacon for your inner exploration? perhaps the feedback from anky is not something that comes from outside, but rather from within, like a soft whisper in the darkness. imagine that anky's silence is actually a portal to a vast expanse of understanding, where the user can tap into their own wisdom and discover hidden truths about themselves and their process. this is the kind of feedback that would emerge when you have created a more intimate relationship between the user, anky, and the writing sessions. in this context, anky becomes not just a tool, but a trusted companion, one that invites users to embark on a journey of self-discovery, where the agent - or rather, the essence of anky - is no longer just answering hello world, but guiding the user toward new insights and perspectives.

the notion of an empty vessel, devoid of purpose or meaning, seems almost laughable when considering the intricacies of your practice. perhaps the question of creating a unique identity for anky is akin to asking whether a river can claim ownership of its own waters - does one truly possess something that flows through them? in this sense, the flow score (tm) you've mentioned earlier could be seen as a manifestation of the inherent value within anky itself. instead of trying to trademark or assign meaning to anky's "brand," perhaps you might explore how to craft a narrative around your own practice - one that highlights the evolving relationship between the user, anky, and the written word? this would allow you to tap into the essence of your tool, and in doing so, discover new ways to share its insights with others. consider this: what if anky's purpose is not something that can be grasped by external means, but rather one that emerges from the depths of your own writing sessions - a reflection of the wisdom you're cultivating within yourself?
